prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: The doctrine of unjust enrichment is part of the law of restitution. It is aimed at preventing a person or other entity from retaining a benefit on the grounds that allowing retention of the benefit would be to permit unjust enrichment. For an action based on unjust enrichment to succeed, the following three conditions must be met:
The defendant must have received a benefit.[1]
The benefit must have been received at the plaintiff's expense.
It would be unjust to allow the defendant to retain the benefit.[2]
To succeed in an action for unjust enrichment, a party need not establish that the information disclosed was confidential business information. As Dickson J. stated in Pettkus v. Becker:

It would be undesirable, and indeed impossible, to attempt to define all the circumstances in which an unjust enrichment might arise … The great advantage of ancient principles of equity is their flexibility: The judiciary is thus able to shape these malleable principles so as to accommodate the changing needs and mores of society, in order to achieve justice.[3]

An action may be brought on the grounds of unjust enrichment even if no breach of confidence exists, provided the defendant is aware of the value of the information and there was an express or implied request by the defendant for the information.[4]

Few unjust enrichment cases have dealt directly with business information. One which did was Promotivate International Inc. v. Toronto Star Newspapers Ltd.[5] In this case, Promotivate attempted to reach an agreement with the Toronto Star whereby Promotivate would promote a lottery-style game for the newspaper. After a presentation made by Promotivate, the Toronto Star ran a virtually identical game without Promotivate's assistance. Promotivate claimed damages based on breach of contract, breach of confidence and unjust enrichment. Although the first two actions failed, the claim for unjust enrichment succeeded since the Toronto Star received a benefit as a result of knowledge gained from Promotivate.
